mods.abstract: FIFTY DOLLARS REWARD. -- RAN away on the morning of July 31st, from No. 156 Gravier street, the bright mulatto girl named MARY SNEAD, well known in the First and Second Districts, and by the police and cabmen generally. Said girl has been in litigation for some time back between Abrams and Bear. Has straight hair, cut ahout half way down here neck ; is of dissolute habits, and would probably be found hanging around some quateroon houses in the rear of the city. The above reward will be paid for the delivery of the girl at my office, or in any jail so that I can get her. One hundred dollars will be paid for the conviction of any white many who may have harbored or induced said slave to abscond, as I believe some white person has induced her to go away and still conceals her. THOMAS J. FRISBY, 156 Common street. au4 tf
mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections ( http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special )

detail.title: New Orleans daily crescent. ([New Orleans, La.]) 1851-1866

mods.accessCondition: E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments about the collection.

Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domain. Permission to reproduce this image must be requested through the Special Collections Department, Louisiana State University Libraries.
mods.note: Louisiana Runaway Slave Advertisements, 1836-1865, Louisiana Digital Library, Baton Rouge, La.
